Description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and the Office of Thrift Supervision announced a settlement agreement with Chicago Title Insurance Company following a joint investigation that uncovered suspected acts of residential and commercial mortgage fraud in the Houston, Texas real estate market.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development announced an agreement with Fidelity National Financial, Inc. to settle allegations the title company paid real estate brokers and other settlement service providers improper kickbacks or referral fees in violation of the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Lender Processing Services Inc., a publicly traded mortgage servicing company based in Jacksonville, Fla., agreed to pay $35 million in criminal penalties and forfeiture to address its alleged participation in a six-year scheme to prepare and file more than 1 million fraudulently signed and notarized mortgage-related documents with property recorders offices throughout the United States.

The Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency fined ServiceLink Holdings, LLC $65 million for improper actions by its predecessor company, Lender Processing Services, Inc. (LPS), which resulted in significant deficiencies in the foreclosure-related services that LPS provided to mortgage servicers.

Lender Processing Services Inc. agreed to pay $120 million to resolve multistate allegations that the firm improperly engaged in pervasive "robo-signing" of foreclosure documents and other faulty servicing practices while servicing loans of struggling homeowners.

Lender Processing Services, Inc. agreed to pay $1.8 million to the state as part of settlement of allegations its subsidiary DOCX falsely signed mortgage documents. This was separate from other state and federal investigations of the company's robo-signing practices.

Lender Processing Services agreed to pay $250,000 in settlement of allegations it engaged in practices known as robo-signing and surrogate-signing when preparing and executing mortgage-related documents, some of which were ultimately filed with county Recorder of Deeds offices throughout Delaware in 2008 and 2009.
Notes: There was also a multistate settlement for similar offences.

Description: Lender Processing Services agreed to pay $2.5 million in a separate settlement with Michigan over allegations its subsidiary DocX fraudulently signed mortgage documents to speed up foreclosures.
Notes: Company agreed to multistate settlement over similar allegations at the same time, but Michigan was a separate investigation and settlement.

Description: Lender Processing Services, Inc. agreed to pay $2 million to the state as part of settlement of allegations its subsidiary DOCX falsely signed mortgage documents. Other state and federal investigations over the robo-signing scandal were ongoing.

After choosing not to participate in the $120 multistate settlement with Lender Processing Services over abusive mortgage practices, Nevada reached its own resolution with the company, which had taken the new name Black Knight Financial Services.

Fidelity National Financial, Inc. entered into a settlement in the amount of $873,588 with California district attorneys in an unfair competition lawsuit regarding Fidelity's Transaction Point real estate software system.

Agency: Arizona Department of Insurance and Financial Institutions
Notes: This case was brought by the Arizona Department of Insurance before it merged with the Department of Financial Institutions.

Company: American Title Co. dba Ticor Title Company of America
Description: American Title Co. dba Ticor Title Company of America agreed to pay a $1.2 million penalty in settlement of allegations it engaged in prohibited rebating activities.

Company: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Co. et al.
Description: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Co., Lawyers Title Insurance Corp., and Transnation Title Insurance Co., all affiliates of LandAmerica, agreed to pay penalties of $1,724,999 and $174,998 in costs, and to repay excessive premiums to a aggregate of $2,600,000, in settlement of allegations their captive insurance arrangements constituted unfair competition, deceptive practices, and unlawful rebates.
